answer_html: Then if \(\displaystyle Av = 0\), we have \(\displaystyle Bv = 0\), so 0 is an eigenvalue for \(\displaystyle B\) as well (in this case, v is also an eigenvector for this special eigenvalue).
answer_latex:
Then if
$\displaystyle Av = 0$, we have $\displaystyle Bv = 0$,
so 0 is an eigenvalue for $\displaystyle B$ as well (in this case,
\emph{v} is also an eigenvector for this special eigenvalue).
hints_html:
Elementary row operations are

  • row switching

  • row multiplication by a non-zero constant

  • row addition

Do any of these change the value of the determinant?

A matrix is invertible if its determinant is non-zero. Can elementary row operations transform a matrix that had a non-zero determinant to a matrix with determinant zero?

Eigenvectors are very specific to a matrix. Multiplying a matrix A with e1 returns the first column of A. That is, if aj is the j-th column of A,

\[\begin{aligned} A = \begin{bmatrix} a_1 & | & a_2 & | & \dots & | & a_n \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

then

\[\begin{aligned} Ae_1 = \begin{bmatrix} a_1 & | & a_2 & | & \dots & | & a_n \end{bmatrix}e_1 = a_1\end{aligned}\]

Since v = e1 is an eigenvector of the matrix A we know that

\[\begin{aligned} Av &= \lambda v \\ Ae_1 &= \lambda e_1 = \begin{bmatrix} \lambda \\ 0 \\ \vdots \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

Hence a1 = \(\lambda\) e1. In other words, the only non-zero entry of the first column of A is in the first row. Can you perform elementary row operations to move that entry into another row, and hence find a counter example?

Do any of these change the value of the determinant?

A matrix is invertible if its determinant is non-zero. Can elementary

matrix with determinant zero?
hints_raw:
Elementary row operations are
* row switching
* row multiplication by a non-zero constant
* row addition

Do any of these change the value of the determinant?
A matrix is invertible if its determinant is non-zero. Can elementary row operations transform a matrix that had a non-zero determinant to a matrix with determinant zero?
Eigenvectors are very specific to a matrix. Multiplying a matrix ''A'' with ''e<sub>1</sub>'' returns the first column of ''A''. That is, if ''a<sub>j'' is the ''j''-th column of ''A'',

:<math>
A = \begin{bmatrix}
a_1 & | & a_2 & | & \dots & | & a_n
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

then 
:<math>
Ae_1 = \begin{bmatrix}
a_1 & | & a_2 & | & \dots & | & a_n
\end{bmatrix}e_1 = a_1
</math>

Since ''v = e<sub>1</sub>'' is an eigenvector of the matrix ''A'' we know that

:<math> \begin{align}
Av &= \lambda v \\
Ae_1 &= \lambda e_1 = \begin{bmatrix} \lambda \\ 0 \\ \vdots \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}
\end{align} </math>

Hence ''a<sub>1</sub> = &lambda; e<sub>1</sub>''. In other words, the only non-zero entry of the first column of ''A'' is in the first row. Can you perform elementary row operations to move that entry into another row, and hence find a counter example?
question: A 15
sols_html:
(b) and (d) are the only correct statements independent of \(A\) and \(B\).

(a) Recall that scaling a row is an elementary row operation which scales the determinant by the same factor, so if the determinant of \(A\) is non-zero, \(\displaystyle \det A = \det B\) can fail to hold.

(b) All elementary row operations can be represented by invertible matrices, so since \(B\) is a product of these matrices, if \(B\) is invertible, then so is \(A\). Alternatively, recall that elementary row operations can only scale the determinant of a matrix by a non-zero factor. Thus, if \(\displaystyle \det B\) is non-zero (i.e. it is invertible) then \(\displaystyle \det A\) is non-zero (so is invertible as well).

(c) This is false, elementary row operations do change eigenvectors. For a simple example, let \(A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\) and \(B = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\). Subtracting the first row from the second row reduces B to A. However, \(\displaystyle Av = v\), so v is an eigenvector of A, while

\[\begin{aligned} Bv = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

which is not a multiple of v. Hence v is not an eigenvector of B.

(d) If \(\displaystyle \lambda=0\) is an eigenvalue of A, then A is not invertible and the determinant of A is 0. As in (b), elementary row operations only scale the determinant by a constant non-zero factor. Therefore, the \(\displaystyle \det(B) = c(\det(A)) = c(0) = 0\) and hence B is not invertible. Hence \(\displaystyle \lambda=0\) is also an eigenvalue of B.

Alternatively, applying an elementary row operation can be represented by multiplication of the original matrix by an elementary matrix (which is invertible). Suppose \(\displaystyle B = EA\). Then if \(\displaystyle Av = 0\), we have \(\displaystyle Bv = E(Av) = E(0) = 0\), so 0 is an eigenvalue for \(\displaystyle B\) as well (in this case, v is also an eigenvector for this special eigenvalue).
sols_latex:
(b) and (d) are the only correct statements independent of $A$ and $B$.

(a) Recall that scaling a row is an elementary row operation which
scales the determinant by the same factor, so if the determinant of $A$
is non-zero, $\displaystyle \det A = \det B$ can fail to hold.

(b) All elementary row operations can be represented by invertible
matrices, so since $B$ is a product of these matrices, if $B$ is
invertible, then so is $A$. Alternatively, recall that elementary row
operations can only scale the determinant of a matrix by a non-zero
factor. Thus, if $\displaystyle \det B$ is non-zero (i.e. it is
invertible) then $\displaystyle \det A$ is non-zero (so is invertible as
well).

(c) This is false, elementary row operations do change eigenvectors. For
a simple example, let $A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$
and $B = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$. Subtracting the
first row from the second row reduces \emph{B} to \emph{A}. However,
$\displaystyle Av = v$, so \emph{v} is an eigenvector of \emph{A}, while

\begin{align*}
Bv = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}
\end{align*}
which is not a multiple of \emph{v}. Hence \emph{v} is not an
eigenvector of \emph{B}.

(d) If $\displaystyle \lambda=0$ is an eigenvalue of \emph{A}, then
\emph{A} is not invertible and the determinant of \emph{A} is 0. As in
(b), elementary row operations only scale the determinant by a constant
non-zero factor. Therefore, the
$\displaystyle \det(B) = c(\det(A)) = c(0) = 0$ and hence \emph{B} is
not invertible. Hence $\displaystyle \lambda=0$ is also an eigenvalue
of \emph{B}.

Alternatively, applying an elementary row operation can be represented
by multiplication of the original matrix by an elementary matrix (which
is invertible). Suppose $\displaystyle B = EA$. Then if
$\displaystyle Av = 0$, we have $\displaystyle Bv = E(Av) = E(0) = 0$,
so 0 is an eigenvalue for $\displaystyle B$ as well (in this case,
\emph{v} is also an eigenvector for this special eigenvalue).

(b) and (d) are the only correct statements independent of <math> A </math> and <math> B </math>. 

(a) Recall that scaling a row is an elementary row operation which scales the determinant by the same factor, so if the determinant of <math> A </math> is non-zero, <math>\displaystyle \det A = \det B </math> can fail to hold.

(b) All elementary row operations can be represented by invertible matrices, so since <math> B </math> is a product of these matrices, if <math> B </math> is invertible, then so is <math> A </math>. Alternatively, recall that elementary row operations can only scale the determinant of a matrix by a non-zero factor. Thus, if <math>\displaystyle \det B </math> is non-zero (i.e. it is invertible) then <math>\displaystyle \det A </math> is non-zero (so is invertible as well).

(c) This is false, elementary row operations do change eigenvectors. For a simple example, let <math>A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}</math> and <math>B = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}</math>. Subtracting the first row from the second row reduces ''B'' to ''A''. However, <math>\displaystyle Av = v</math>, so ''v'' is an eigenvector of ''A'', while
:<math>Bv = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} </math>
which is not a multiple of ''v''. Hence ''v'' is not an eigenvector of ''B''.

(d) If <math>\displaystyle  \lambda=0</math> is an eigenvalue of ''A'', then ''A'' is not invertible and the determinant of ''A'' is 0. As in (b), elementary row operations only scale the determinant by a constant non-zero factor. Therefore, the <math> \displaystyle \det(B) = c(\det(A)) = c(0) = 0</math> and hence ''B'' is not invertible. Hence <math>\displaystyle  \lambda=0</math> is also an eigenvalue of ''B''.

Alternatively, applying an elementary row operation can be represented by multiplication of the original matrix by an elementary matrix (which is invertible). Suppose <math> \displaystyle  B = EA </math>. Then if <math> \displaystyle  Av = 0 </math>, we have <math> \displaystyle  Bv = E(Av) = E(0) = 0 </math>, so 0 is an eigenvalue for <math> \displaystyle  B </math> as well (in this case, ''v'' is also an eigenvector for this special eigenvalue).
statement_html:
Assume that the matrix B was obtained by applying a sequence of elementary row operations to the matrix A. Circle all the correct statements that are true”’independent of what the given”’ A and B are.

(a) \(\displaystyle \det A = \det B\)

(b) If B is invertible then A is also invertible.

(c) If \(v = \begin{bmatrix} 1\\0 \end{bmatrix}\) is an eigenvector of A, then v is also an eigenvector of B.

(d) If \(\lambda = 0\) is an eigenvalue of A, then \(\lambda = 0\) is also an eigenvalue of B.
statement_latex:
Assume that the matrix \emph{B} was obtained by applying a sequence of
elementary row operations to the matrix \emph{A}. Circle \textbf{all}
the correct statements that are true'''independent of what the given''' \emph{A} \textbf{and} \emph{B} \textbf{are.}

(a) $\displaystyle \det A = \det B$

(b) If \emph{B} is invertible then \emph{A} is also invertible.

(c) If $v = \begin{bmatrix} 1\\0 \end{bmatrix}$ is an eigenvector of
\emph{A}, then \emph{v} is also an eigenvector of \emph{B}.

(d) If $\lambda = 0$ is an eigenvalue of \emph{A}, then $\lambda = 0$ is
also an eigenvalue of \emph{B}.
statement_raw:
Assume that the matrix ''B'' was obtained by applying a sequence of elementary row operations to the matrix ''A''. Circle '''all''' the correct statements that are true '''independent of what the given ''' ''A'' '''and''' ''B'' '''are.'''

(a) <math>\displaystyle \det A = \det B </math>

(b) If ''B'' is invertible then ''A'' is also invertible.

(c) If <math> v = \begin{bmatrix} 1\\0 \end{bmatrix} </math> is an eigenvector of ''A'', then ''v'' is also an eigenvector of ''B''.

(d) If <math> \lambda = 0 </math> is an eigenvalue of ''A'', then <math> \lambda = 0 </math> is also an eigenvalue of ''B''.
